exercises.instruction: Choose good or well to complete each sentence.

items.prompt: 1) She speaks English very ____.
2) The film was ____ but a little long.
3) You did ____ on the driving test.
4) It’s a ____ idea to leave early.
5) I didn’t sleep ____ last night.
6) He’s a ____ cook, but he doesn’t cook often.
7) The kids behaved ____ during the trip.
8) Your pronunciation is really ____.

exercises.instruction: Make compound adjectives with well- (use a hyphen).

items.prompt: 1) Complete with a compound adjective: known → ____.
2) Complete with a compound adjective: paid → ____.
3) Complete with a compound adjective: educated → ____.
4) Complete with a compound adjective: behaved → ____.
5) Complete with a compound adjective: written → ____.
6) Complete with a compound adjective: designed → ____.

exercises.instruction: Complete each sentence with fast, hard, late, or lately.

items.prompt: 1) He’s a ____ runner, but he can’t run ____ now. (use fast)
2) I’m sorry I’m ____. I missed the earlier bus.
3) Have you seen Mia ____? (= recently)
4) This puzzle is ____; I can’t do it quickly. (use hard)
5) She works really ____ when she has deadlines.
6) Don’t drive too ____ in town.
7) We arrived ____ because of traffic.
8) I’ve been eating healthier ____. (= in recent weeks)
9) It’s ____ to concentrate with this noise.

exercises.instruction: Choose hard or hardly.

items.prompt: 1) I ____ know her. We’ve only met once.
2) He studied ____ for the exam, so he passed.
3) She tried ____, but she still couldn’t open the jar.
4) We ____ had any time to talk at the party.
5) It was foggy; I could ____ see the road.
6) Don’t say he’s lazy. He works ____ every day.
7) I ____ slept on the flight.

exercises.instruction: Complete each sentence with the correct word or expression.

items.prompt: 1) The report is ____ written. (compound)
2) I’m doing ____ today, thanks. (after 'be')
3) Sorry I’m ____. (not on time)
4) I haven’t seen them ____.
5) She plays the guitar really ____.
6) The children were very ____.
7) I ____ noticed the change at first.
8) He drives too ____ on the motorway.
9) I worked ____ all week.
10) The book was ____ and easy to read.
11) This is a ____-known problem.

exercises.instruction: Choose so or such.

items.prompt: 1) It was ____ cold that the lake froze overnight.
2) They had ____ a great time at the concert.
3) The lecture was ____ boring that I nearly fell asleep.
4) That’s ____ a strange question.
5) I was ____ tired after the trip.
6) We met ____ friendly neighbours.
7) The phone was ____ expensive that I didn’t buy it.
8) It was ____ a relief to hear the news.
9) She speaks ____ quietly that I can’t hear her.
10) It was ____ a useful app that everyone installed it.

exercises.instruction: Complete with so much, so many, so little, or so few.

items.prompt: 1) There were ____ people that we couldn’t get in.
2) I have ____ work to finish tonight.
3) We had ____ time that we skipped lunch.
4) He made ____ mistakes in that email.
5) She has ____ patience with rude customers.
6) They spent ____ money on the wedding.
7) There were ____ seats left.
8) I ate ____ snacks that I wasn’t hungry for dinner.
9) We got ____ information that we felt lost.

exercises.instruction: Complete with so or such. Use that where it fits (____).

items.prompt: 1) The street was ____ noisy ____ I couldn’t sleep.
2) It was ____ a mess ____ we had to start again.
3) The box was ____ heavy ____ I couldn’t lift it.
4) She told ____ a funny story ____ everyone laughed.
5) The movie was ____ long ____ we left early.
6) They had ____ bad luck ____ they gave up.
7) I was ____ hungry ____ I ate two sandwiches.
8) It was ____ a good offer ____ I accepted immediately.

exercises.instruction: Rewrite the sentences using so/such ... that.

items.prompt: 1) Rewrite using so/such ... that: Very hot. We stayed indoors.
items.canonical: It was so hot that we stayed indoors.
accepted_variants: It was so hot that we stayed indoors.
it was so hot that we stayed indoors.
It was so hot that we stayed indoors

items.prompt: 2) Rewrite using so/such ... that: The book was very interesting. I read it in one day.
items.canonical: The book was so interesting that I read it in one day.
accepted_variants: The book was so interesting that I read it in one day.
The book was so interesting that I read it in one day
the book was so interesting that I read it in one day.

items.prompt: 3) Rewrite using so/such ... that: It was a terrible storm. Flights were cancelled.
items.canonical: It was such a terrible storm that flights were cancelled.
accepted_variants: It was such a terrible storm that flights were cancelled.
it was such a terrible storm that flights were cancelled.
It was such a terrible storm that flights were cancelled

items.prompt: 4) Rewrite using so/such ... that: The coffee was very strong. I couldn’t finish it.
items.canonical: The coffee was so strong that I couldn’t finish it.
accepted_variants: The coffee was so strong that I couldn’t finish it.
The coffee was so strong that I couldn’t finish it
the coffee was so strong that I couldn’t finish it.

items.prompt: 5) Rewrite using so/such ... that: They were very kind people. They offered us a room.
items.canonical: They were such kind people that they offered us a room.
accepted_variants: They were such kind people that they offered us a room.
they were such kind people that they offered us a room.
They were such kind people that they offered us a room

items.prompt: 6) Rewrite using so/such ... that: The queue was very long. We went home.
items.canonical: The queue was so long that we went home.
accepted_variants: The queue was so long that we went home.
The queue was so long that we went home
the queue was so long that we went home.

items.prompt: 7) Rewrite using so/such ... that: It was a difficult decision. I needed time.
items.canonical: It was such a difficult decision that I needed time.
accepted_variants: It was such a difficult decision that I needed time.
It was such a difficult decision that I needed time
it was such a difficult decision that I needed time.

exercises.instruction: Add enough in the correct place.

items.prompt: 1) The soup isn’t hot ____.
2) Are you strong ____ to lift that box?
3) You don’t drive carefully ____.
4) This room is big ____ for ten people.
5) I’m not old ____ to rent a car.
6) He didn’t speak clearly ____.
7) The Wi‑Fi is fast ____ for video calls.
8) She didn’t train hard ____.
9) Is the explanation simple ____?
10) I didn’t get up early ____.

exercises.instruction: Complete with too (and the noun phrase already given).

items.prompt: 1) This jacket is ____ small for me.
2) I drank ____ much coffee and couldn’t sleep.
3) There were ____ many people to park easily.
4) The music is ____ loud.
5) I spent ____ much money this week.
6) The explanation is ____ complicated.
7) We have ____ many meetings today.
8) He talks ____ fast for me to follow.

exercises.instruction: Rewrite using too ... to or (not) ... enough to.

items.prompt: 1) Rewrite using too ... to / (not) ... enough to: I was very tired. I couldn’t finish the report.
items.canonical: I was too tired to finish the report.
accepted_variants: I was too tired to finish the report.
i was too tired to finish the report.
I was too tired to finish the report

items.prompt: 2) Rewrite using too ... to / (not) ... enough to: She is 15. She can’t vote.
items.canonical: She isn’t old enough to vote.
accepted_variants: She isn’t old enough to vote.
She isn’t old enough to vote
she isn’t old enough to vote.

items.prompt: 3) Rewrite using too ... to / (not) ... enough to: The bag was very heavy. I couldn’t carry it.
items.canonical: The bag was too heavy to carry.
accepted_variants: The bag was too heavy to carry.
the bag was too heavy to carry.
The bag was too heavy to carry

items.prompt: 4) Rewrite using too ... to / (not) ... enough to: He didn’t have the skill. He couldn’t fix it.
items.canonical: He wasn’t experienced enough to fix it.
accepted_variants: He wasn’t experienced enough to fix it.
He wasn’t experienced enough to fix it
he wasn’t experienced enough to fix it.

items.prompt: 5) Rewrite using too ... to / (not) ... enough to: We arrived late. We missed the start.
items.canonical: We arrived too late to catch the start.
accepted_variants: We arrived too late to catch the start.
we arrived too late to catch the start.
We arrived too late to catch the start

items.prompt: 6) Rewrite using too ... to / (not) ... enough to: The coffee is very hot. I can’t drink it.
items.canonical: The coffee is too hot to drink.
accepted_variants: The coffee is too hot to drink.
the coffee is too hot to drink.
The coffee is too hot to drink

items.prompt: 7) Rewrite using too ... to / (not) ... enough to: The explanation was clear. I could understand.
items.canonical: The explanation was clear enough to understand.
accepted_variants: The explanation was clear enough to understand.
the explanation was clear enough to understand.
The explanation was clear enough to understand

items.prompt: 8) Rewrite using too ... to / (not) ... enough to: I don’t have time. I can’t go now.
items.canonical: I don’t have enough time to go now.
accepted_variants: I don’t have enough time to go now.
I don’t have enough time to go now
i don’t have enough time to go now.

items.prompt: 9) Rewrite using too ... to / (not) ... enough to: He’s very young. He can’t drive.

exercises.instruction: Choose pretty or fairly.

items.prompt: 1) I’m ____ tired, but I can keep working.
2) The instructions were ____ clear.
3) It’s ____ easy to get there by метро.
4) She was ____ upset about it.
5) The film was ____ good.
6) The room is ____ small.
7) I’m ____ sure he’s right.

exercises.instruction: Complete with quite (meaning 'fairly') where it fits.

items.prompt: 1) The hotel was ____ nice (better than OK).
2) I’m ____ happy with the result.
3) The task is ____ simple.
4) It’s ____ a long walk from here.
5) She’s ____ good at languages.
6) We’ve had ____ a busy week.
7) The café is ____ popular.

exercises.instruction: Use quite (meaning 'completely') with these adjectives.

items.prompt: 1) I’m ____ sure (= completely certain).
2) The bottle is ____ empty.
3) That’s ____ impossible.
4) The two designs are ____ different.
5) I’m ____ satisfied now.

exercises.instruction: Complete with rather.

items.prompt: 1) It’s ____ cold for April.
2) The meeting was ____ boring.
3) That’s ____ rude, isn’t it?
4) I’m ____ surprised you agreed.
5) This sofa is ____ uncomfortable.
6) The price is ____ high.
7) It feels ____ strange to be back here.

exercises.instruction: Choose the best word: pretty, fairly, quite, or rather.

items.prompt: 1) It was ____ a surprise to see him there.
2) That’s ____ a good idea.
3) We had ____ a difficult day.
4) It’s ____ a mess in here.
5) She’s ____ confident today. (moderate)
6) The exam was ____ easy. (moderate)
7) The house is ____ expensive, considering the size.

exercises.instruction: Write the comparative form.

items.prompt: 1) Write the comparative: cheap → ____.
2) Write the comparative: young → ____.
3) Write the comparative: easy → ____.
4) Write the comparative: big → ____.
5) Write the comparative: thin → ____.
6) Write the comparative: hot → ____.
7) Write the comparative: nice → ____.
8) Write the comparative: busy → ____.
9) Write the comparative: good → ____.
10) Write the comparative: bad → ____.
11) Write the comparative: far → ____.
12) Write the comparative: interesting → ____.

exercises.instruction: Complete with the comparative (use than).

items.prompt: 1) My phone is ____ (new) than yours.
2) This chair is ____ (comfortable) than that one.
3) Today is ____ (cold) than yesterday.
4) The blue route is ____ (short) than the red route.
5) Her second attempt was ____ (good) than the first.
6) This task is ____ (easy) than I expected.
7) Kyiv is ____ (big) than my hometown.
8) The new plan is ____ (bad) than the old one.
9) This explanation is ____ (clear) than the previous one.
10) The hotel was ____ (expensive) than we thought.

exercises.instruction: Write the correct comparative (‑er or more).

items.prompt: 1) She’s getting ____ (careful) as she practises.
2) This book is ____ (useful) than the first one.
3) The test was ____ (simple) than I expected.
4) A bus is ____ (slow) than a train.
5) Your answer is ____ (polite) than mine.
6) The screen is ____ (bright) on this model.
7) It’s ____ (difficult) to explain than to show.
8) I feel ____ (tired) today.

exercises.instruction: Complete with a comparative. Use than only if needed.

items.prompt: 1) It’s colder today, but tomorrow will be even ____.
2) I expected the trip to be cheaper, but it was ____.
3) The second explanation was ____.
4) I thought the job would be easier. In reality it’s ____.
5) This chair looks newer, but it’s actually ____ than the other.
6) The new update made the app ____ to use.

exercises.instruction: Complete with much/far/a lot + comparative.

items.prompt: 1) This exercise is ____ (easy) than the last one.
2) The new laptop is ____ (expensive) than mine.
3) I feel ____ (good) today.
4) The new version is ____ (useful) than the old one.
5) The sea is ____ (cold) than I expected.
6) This route is ____ (long) than the other.
7) Her English is ____ (fluent) now.

exercises.instruction: Complete with a bit/a little/slightly + comparative.

items.prompt: 1) I’m ____ (tired) than yesterday.
2) This room is ____ (small) than the other one.
3) The soup needs to be ____ (hot).
4) The second option is ____ (cheap).
5) The result is ____ (good) now.

exercises.instruction: Complete with any or no (use no longer where needed).

items.prompt: 1) Is it ____ cheaper online?
2) I don’t think it’s ____ better than before.
3) The situation is ____ worse now.
4) I’m not ____ interested in that topic anymore.
5) She’s ____ longer working here.

exercises.instruction: Complete with the correct pronoun/clause after than.

items.prompt: 1) She’s older than ____.
2) He’s not as tall as you, but he’s taller than ____ ____.
3) This computer is faster than ____.
4) She’s more organised than ____ ____.
5) They earn more than ____.

exercises.instruction: Complete with comparative patterns (… and … / the … the …).

items.prompt: 1) Complete: My English is improving. It’s getting ____.
2) Complete: The weather is changing. It’s getting ____.

9) Complete: The older I get, the ____ I am.
10) Complete: The bigger the city, the ____ traffic there is.
11) Complete: Her health is improving. She feels ____.

exercises.instruction: Complete with as ... as.

items.prompt: 1) He can run ____ (fast) his brother.
2) My bag is ____ (heavy) yours.
3) This test isn’t ____ (difficult) it looks.
4) She doesn’t drive ____ (carefully) her mum.
5) The apartment is ____ (quiet) at night.
6) I’m ____ (tall) you.
7) Please answer ____ (quickly) you can.

exercises.instruction: Complete with not as/so ... as (write the phrase as ... as).

items.prompt: 1) This phone isn’t ____ (expensive) the other one.
2) I’m not ____ (fit) I used to be.
3) The bus is not ____ (reliable) the train.
4) The soup wasn’t ____ (hot) I expected.

6) Today isn’t ____ (windy) yesterday.
7) The film wasn’t ____ (good) the reviews said.
8) My laptop is not ____ (powerful) yours.

exercises.instruction: Complete with as much/many/few/little ... as.

items.prompt: 1) I don’t have ____ (much time) you.
2) We didn’t get ____ (many answers) we hoped for.

4) There aren’t ____ (many seats) last year.

6) He has ____ (little patience) his brother.

exercises.instruction: Write the correct comparison phrase (… than / as … as).

items.prompt: 1) Choose the correct comparison: I’m ____ (old) my brother. (use than)
2) Choose the correct comparison: This room is ____ (big) the other one. (use than)
3) Choose the correct comparison: I’m ____ (tall) you. (use as ... as)
4) Choose the correct comparison: The train is ____ (fast) the bus. (use than)

exercises.instruction: Complete with the correct comparative structure.

items.prompt: 1) Complete: My car is ____ (not / old) yours.
2) Complete: She’s ____ (intelligent) her sister.

exercises.instruction: Put the words in the correct order.

items.prompt: 1) Put the words in order: (bought / a new laptop / I / yesterday)
items.canonical: I bought a new laptop yesterday.
accepted_variants: I bought a new laptop yesterday.
I bought a new laptop yesterday
i bought a new laptop yesterday.

items.prompt: 2) Put the words in order: (reads / every evening / my sister / novels)
items.canonical: My sister reads novels every evening.
accepted_variants: My sister reads novels every evening.
my sister reads novels every evening.
My sister reads novels every evening

items.prompt: 3) Put the words in order: (found / on the floor / I / your keys)
items.canonical: I found your keys on the floor.
accepted_variants: I found your keys on the floor.
i found your keys on the floor.
I found your keys on the floor

items.prompt: 4) Put the words in order: (met / at a café / we / last week)
items.canonical: We met at a café last week.
accepted_variants: We met at a café last week.
We met at a café last week
we met at a café last week.

items.prompt: 5) Put the words in order: (sent / an email / he / this morning)
items.canonical: He sent an email this morning.
accepted_variants: He sent an email this morning.
He sent an email this morning
he sent an email this morning.

items.prompt: 6) Put the words in order: (watched / at home / they / the match)
items.canonical: They watched the match at home.
accepted_variants: They watched the match at home.
they watched the match at home.
They watched the match at home

items.prompt: 7) Put the words in order: (saw / in the park / I / her)
items.canonical: I saw her in the park.
accepted_variants: I saw her in the park.
I saw her in the park
i saw her in the park.

items.prompt: 8) Put the words in order: (cooked / for dinner / she / pasta)
9) Put the words in order: (lost / on the bus / I / my wallet)
items.canonical: I lost my wallet on the bus.
accepted_variants: I lost my wallet on the bus.
i lost my wallet on the bus.
I lost my wallet on the bus

items.prompt: 10) Put the words in order: (spoke / after class / we / to the teacher)
items.canonical: We spoke to the teacher after class.
accepted_variants: We spoke to the teacher after class.
we spoke to the teacher after class.
We spoke to the teacher after class

items.prompt: 11) Put the words in order: (fixed / quickly / he / the problem)
12) Put the words in order: (invited / to the party / they / us)
items.canonical: They invited us to the party.
accepted_variants: They invited us to the party.
They invited us to the party
they invited us to the party.

exercises.instruction: Put place before time.

items.prompt: 1) Correct order (place + time): I met him ____ ____ . (at the station / this morning)
2) Correct order (place + time): We stayed ____ ____ . (in Lviv / last weekend)
3) Correct order (place + time): She studied ____ ____ . (at home / yesterday)
4) Correct order (place + time): I left my bag ____ ____ . (in the car / last night)
5) Correct order (place + time): They had lunch ____ ____ . (in the park / on Sunday)
6) Correct order (place + time): We talked ____ ____ . (in the hallway / after the meeting)
items.canonical: in the hallway after the meeting
accepted_variants: in the hallway after the meeting
in the hallway after the meeting.
In the hallway after the meeting

items.prompt: 7) Correct order (place + time): I saw her ____ ____ . (at work / this afternoon)
8) Correct order (place + time): He slept ____ ____ . (on the sofa / all day)

exercises.instruction: Correct the word order.

items.prompt: 1) Correct the sentence: I went yesterday to the dentist.
items.canonical: I went to the dentist yesterday.
accepted_variants: I went to the dentist yesterday.
I went to the dentist yesterday
i went to the dentist yesterday.

items.canonical: We watched the movie at home.
accepted_variants: We watched the movie at home.
We watched the movie at home
we watched the movie at home.

items.canonical: He drove to the office this morning.
accepted_variants: He drove to the office this morning.
he drove to the office this morning.

items.prompt: 5) Correct the sentence: They in the kitchen were talking.
items.canonical: They were talking in the kitchen.
accepted_variants: They were talking in the kitchen.
they were talking in the kitchen.

items.prompt: 6) Correct the sentence: I found in my pocket the receipt.
items.canonical: I found the receipt in my pocket.
accepted_variants: I found the receipt in my pocket.

items.canonical: She met him in Warsaw last week.
accepted_variants: She met him in Warsaw last week.
she met him in Warsaw last week.

items.prompt: 8) Correct the sentence: We to Spain travelled last year.
items.canonical: We travelled to Spain last year.
accepted_variants: We travelled to Spain last year.
we travelled to Spain last year.

items.prompt: 9) Correct the sentence: He carefully read the instructions.
10) Correct the sentence: I in a taxi came home.
items.canonical: I came home in a taxi.
accepted_variants: I came home in a taxi.
i came home in a taxi.

items.prompt: 11) Correct the sentence: They at the same café meet on Saturdays.
items.canonical: They meet at the same café on Saturdays.
accepted_variants: They meet at the same café on Saturdays.
they meet at the same café on Saturdays.

items.prompt: 12) Correct the sentence: She the email sent immediately.
13) Correct the sentence: We to the cinema went on Friday.
items.canonical: We went to the cinema on Friday.
accepted_variants: We went to the cinema on Friday.
We went to the cinema on Friday

exercises.instruction: Put the adverb in the correct place.

items.prompt: 1) Put 'often' in the correct place: I work from home.
2) Put 'always' in the correct place: She drinks coffee in the morning.
items.canonical: She always drinks coffee in the morning.
accepted_variants: She always drinks coffee in the morning.
she always drinks coffee in the morning.
She always drinks coffee in the morning

items.prompt: 3) Put 'usually' in the correct place: We meet on Mondays.
4) Put 'sometimes' in the correct place: They play chess after dinner.
items.canonical: They sometimes play chess after dinner.
accepted_variants: They sometimes play chess after dinner.
they sometimes play chess after dinner.
They sometimes play chess after dinner

items.prompt: 5) Put 'never' in the correct place: I forget my password.
6) Put 'often' in the correct place: He watches tutorials at night.
items.canonical: He often watches tutorials at night.

he often watches tutorials at night.

exercises.instruction: Correct the word order / place the adverb.

items.prompt: 1) Correct the word order: I drink coffee always in the morning.

i always drink coffee in the morning.
